entry.title: Information Overload 2011-07-17
entry.content:
• "How Seawater Can Power the World":http://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/11/opinion/11Prager.html
    Interesting NYT op-ed on the future of fusion energy.
  • "Zoobotics":http://www.economist.com/node/18925855?story_id=18925855
    Robot researchers are modeling their creations after animals now, assuming that it's hard to come up with a better design than evolution.
  • "Edward Tufte's "Slopegraphs"":http://charliepark.org/slopegraphs/
    I really like this under-used chart style, I think it conveys meaning very well.
  • "Groundhog Decade":http://www.slate.com/id/2298871/pagenum/all/
    Very good piece on how Hollywood apparently is dead set on repeating the mistakes of the music industry.
  • "Why Programming Languages?":http://soft.vub.ac.be/~tvcutsem/whypls.html
    A programming language researcher explains why there are so many different programming languages and why we'll likely keep on seeing new ones.
  • "The Menace Within":http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/2011/julaug/features/spe.html
    40 years after the Stanford Prison Experiment some key players tell about their experience and what they took away from the experiment.
  • "Misattribution of Arousal":http://youarenotsosmart.com/2011/07/07/misattribution-of-arousal/
    I love all those insights into how our brains work. This article deals with the misattribution of arousal (not only of the sexual kind) to other people.
  • "How Digital Detectives Deciphered Stuxnet, the Most Menacing Malware in History":http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/07/how-digital-detectives-deciphered-stuxnet/all/1
    If you have the slightest interest in IT security, you'll love this article, but even if you usually don't enjoy this topic the story still reads like the plot of a Hollywood movie.
  • "Tower of David: 45 Floors of Favela Chic":http://d-build.org/blog/?p=2128
    One of Latin America's tallest buildings is now squatted by around 2500 people, many of them escaping live on the streets.
  • "My Summer at an Indian Call Center":http://m.motherjones.com/politics/2011/05/indian-call-center-americanization
    An American citizen works in an Indian call center for a summer.

entry.title: Information Overload 2011-05-15
entry.content:
• "Crunching the numbers: How many people have ever lived?":http://1000memories.com/blog/75-number-of-people-who-have-ever-lived
    Why is math awesome? Because it answers questions like this one. Don't worry, no spoilers ;-)
  • "The Pirate Bay: 'The Battle of Internets is About to Begin'":http://torrentfreak.com/the-pirate-bay-the-battle-of-internets-is-about-to-begin-110509/
    TPB's answer to the threat of a "Great Firewall" in Europe.
  • "2011 Trends":http://www.logolounge.com/article.asp?aid=lnPf
    LongoLounge.com's annual logo design trends.
  • "How to Stop Worrying and Learn to Love the Internet":http://www.douglasadams.com/dna/19990901-00-a.html
    Wow, Douglas Adams already had a better grasp of the internet in 1999 than a lot of the people in decision-making positions have today.
  • "Silver Needle in the Skype":http://www.blackhat.com/presentations/bh-europe-06/bh-eu-06-biondi/bh-eu-06-biondi-up.pdf
    Since everyone was talking about Skype this week, I thought I'd include this very interesting presentation from Black Hat 2006.
  • "The History of Pretty Much Everything":http://scienceblogs.com/startswithabang/2011/04/the_history_of_pretty_much_eve.php
    If you like astronomy and/or physics, you'll probably like this too.
  • "Anonymous: peering behind the mask":http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2011/may/11/anonymous-behind-the-mask
    Pretty good article by "Jana Herwig":http://twitter.com/#!/digiom on Anonymous.
  • "Kill Math":http://worrydream.com/KillMath/
    While I don't agree with everything said, this article does have some interesting points and a great visualization of integration.
  • "Satellite Images of North Korea Prison Camps Find 200,000 Living as Slaves":http://singularityhub.com/2011/05/12/satellite-images-of-north-korea-prison-camps-find-200000-living-as-slaves/
    A follow-up to last week's article by Amnesty International, because this is something we shouldn't forget about.
  • "Are you living in a computer simulation?":http://www.simulation-argument.com/simulation.html
    That's exactly the kind of question I want answered by Oxford's philosophy department.

entry.title: Information Overload 2011-03-20
entry.content:
• "Haskell's Niche: Hard Problems":http://cdsmith.wordpress.com/2011/03/13/haskells-niche-hard-problems/
    Doing more Haskell was on my todo list for 2011, but so far I've failed rather miserably. Oh well, at least I'm reading about it...
  • "Beyond Rules":http://www.friendlyanarchist.com/beyond-rules/
    Nice post with a free download of the ebook "Beyond Rules: A Dilettante's Guide to Personal Sovereignty, Space Travel, and Lots of Ice Cream".
  • "The Tau Manifesto":http://tauday.com/
    The math fans among my readers should like this one (and the accompanying "Half Tau Day":http://halftauday.com/), I certainly did!
  • "Was haben wir aus unserer Welt gemacht?":http://www.misik.at/texte-aus-der-taz-berlin/was-haben-wir-aus-unserer-welt-gemacht.php
    Austrian journalist Robert Misik comments on the current nuclear energy safety discussion (in German).
  • "Antarctica, 1961: A Soviet Surgeon Has to Remove His Own Appendix":http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2011/03/antarctica-1961-a-soviet-surgeon-has-to-remove-his-own-appendix/72445/
    The Chuck Norris of surgery.
  • "Partitioning my digital life into security domains":http://theinvisiblethings.blogspot.com/2011/03/partitioning-my-digital-life-into.html
    Well--known security researcher Joanna Rutkowska describes how she partitions her digital life into separate domains with "Qubes OS":http://qubes-os.org/Home.html. A very interesting approach and I'm curious to see Beta 1 of the OS.
  • "Cosmonaut Crashed Into Earth 'Crying In Rage'":http://www.npr.org/blogs/krulwich/2011/03/18/134597833/cosmonaut-crashed-into-earth-crying-in-rage?ft=1&f=1026
    The man who died to save his friend Yuri Gagarin.
  • "Facebook: Online-Proteste ohne Offline-Effekt":http://futurezone.at/netzpolitik/2282-facebook-online-proteste-ohne-offline-effekt.php
    Good article on "Slacktivism" (in German).
  • "Chomsky on 'Intellectual Property'":http://groups.google.com/group/alt.fan.noam-chomsky/msg/12c9b62ed459d63d?pli=1
    Interview with Noam Chomsky about intellectual property. This is a bit older, but still a good read.
  • "Nerds, we need to have a talk":http://thingist.com/t/item/4372/
    Good rant about an attitude problem in nerd culture.

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-11-14
entry.content:
• "JVM Bytecode for Dummies":http://www.slideshare.net/CharlesNutter/redev-2010-jvm-bytecode-for-dummies
    Awesome presentation by "Charles Nutter":http://blog.headius.com/ on JVM Bytecode. No matter if you are just curious or want to write your own programming language, this is interesting!
  • "Cutting out the middle men":http://www.economist.com/node/17420321?story_id=17420321&fsrc=scn/tw/te/rss/pe
    Great pilot project in the UK, empowering homeless people instead by directly giving them money.
  • "Can't play, won't play":http://www.hideandseek.net/cant-play-wont-play/
    Lots of websites and incentive programs nowadays try to "gamify" themselves by adding badges and point systems. Read why in most cases this has nothing to do with real games.
  • "Obscene Losses":http://www.portfolio.com/culture-lifestyle/culture-inc/arts/2007/10/15/YouPorn-Vivid-Entertainment-Profile/index.html
    Very detailed article on how YouPorn and other amateur sites damage the business of established adult movie producers.
  • "Mystery of how cats lap is revealed":http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-11717510
    Cats even drink in cool ways.
  • "10 centuries in 5 minutes":http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DrZvn1qckIs
    Absolutely fantastic 5 minute video of 1000 years of European history. This is fascinating and a good reminder that today's empires may very well be tomorrow's ashes.
  • "20 Awesomely Untranslatable Words from Around the World":http://matadornetwork.com/abroad/20-awesomely-untranslatable-words-from-around-the-world/2/
    Interesting collection of untranslatable words from around the world. This made the language geek in me very happy.
  • "What I Would Do With This: Groceries":http://blog.mrmeyer.com/?p=4646
    The mathematics of grocery shopping.
  • "Skateistan: To live and skate Kabul":http://vimeo.com/15841377
    Short movie about a co-educational Skateboarding school in Kabul, Afghanistan.
  • "Hubris Versus Humility: The $15 billion Difference":http://steveblank.com/2010/11/08/hubris-versus-humility-the-15-billion-difference/
    While I think that the comparison in this article is a bit apples and oranges, it's an interesting take on initial market positioning.

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-10-17
entry.content:
• "The 'Irrational' Way Humans Interact With Dentists":http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130356647
    Are our relationships with our dentists a form of the "Stockholm Syndrome":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stockholm_syndrome? Ask the behavioral psychologist.
  • "RCA student radically improves the UK plug":http://www.iconeye.com/index.php?id=3864:rca-student-radically-improves-the-uk-plug&option=com_content&view=article
    Awesome redesign of an everyday item.
  • "William Gibson says the future is right here, right now":http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-11502715
    When it comes to the future, who to trust if not William Gibson?
  • "What a scientist didn't tell the New York Times about his study on bee deaths":http://money.cnn.com/2010/10/08/news/honey_bees_ny_times.fortune/index.htm
    Follow-up to last week's NYT article on "Colony Collapse Disorder":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colony_collapse_disorder. How is "Bayer":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayer related to all of this?
  • "Die kritische Masse":http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/0,1518,722673,00.html
    Interesting article on online review portals, user motivation and manipulation (in German).
  • "Whistleblower reveals 'systematic' humiliation of detainees":http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2010/10/whistleblower-reveals-systematic-humiliation/
    When reading things like this, "what goes around comes around" is always my first sad thought.
  • "The Numbers Game":http://structureofnews.wordpress.com/2010/10/12/the-numbers-game/
    A plea to increase "numeracy":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numeracy amongst journalists. Amen to that!
  • "Sweden joins Europe-wide backlash against immigration":http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/sep/24/sweden-immigration-far-right-asylum
    Sweden joins the ranks of European countries where xeno- and Islamophobia win elections. Also contains a short summary of similar developments all over Europe.
  • "Irish ISP wins major legal victory against record labels":http://www.techeye.net/internet/irish-isp-wins-major-legal-victory-against-record-labels
    UPC wins a court case against the record industry and does not have to implement a three strikes system for its customers (for now).
  • "Council of Europe Agrees That Net neutrality is Key to Freedom of Expression":http://www.laquadrature.net/en/council-of-europe-agrees-that-net-neutrality-is-key-to-freedom-of-expression
    Some more good news on the freedom of expression front.
